description.text: Hi everyone, This is my first thing i have uploaded. I designed this scotch tape dispenser for scotch tape that's 50 mm wide. I don't know what the normal width is in the rest of the world, so i have included the google sketchup files. Maybe you can modify this for your needs. I don't have my printer yet, so i don't know how the printer will handle this model

I think that it must be printed with support

  • Print it.

  • remove the support.

  • insert the scotch tape into the dispenser with the sticky side up.

Tevo Tarantula Bowden Seal
(any typical 4mm bowden and 1.75mm filament)

This is a coupler that will hold an oring to seal the filament in the bowden, and a PC4-M6 on each end.

The oring is a 1.5mm id x 1.8mm thick and can be found on ebay as a common rc helicopter part. They run ~$5 for 10.
Search " Lynx Blade 180 CFX 10pc Silicone O-Ring Set ID 1.5mm ID 1.8mm W LX1506 ".

There are two versions.
V1 is simpler, but might not work with all pc4-m6 fittings.
V2 has more parts, but should work with any pc4-m6.

I'm still goofing around with it to see if this will even do anything, but so far it looks promising.

This cork is used to seal off the Miata's transmission output shaft to prevent any fluid loss when working on the car. I used the cork when I was pulling the engine and trans out and didn't want to lose any of my precious Royal Purple. Worked flawlessly!

I've used this on the 5 speed transmissions. From what I've read the 6 speeds have the same drive shaft diameter, so it should work for those as well.

Printer:

Tronxy X1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Shiming

Depending on the accuracy of your printer, you may need to shim the cork with some electrical tape. This also helps smooth the plug over and prevent the printed layers from catching on the seal's rubber lip. Be careful because the seal has a rubber flap that helps push up against the driver shaft to seal it off; if you shim too much, you can risk folding the rubber lip in. Folding the lip in can deform the rubber and prevent it from doing it's job properly once the drive shaft is back in. It doesn't have to be a super snug fit.

description.text:
Now with the Port wing... Sorry for missing the file.
This model was developed from the Lancaster model here http://www.cadnav.com/3d-models/model-29109.html. I split the model and inserted keys to bring it all together. You can print it at 300% scale on a 20cm x 20cm print bed. The undercarriage doors don't work at these scales as they are too thin but it looks fine without them.
I have not printed the props yet as they might work better if I print all found at the same time or do some more tweaking as they are very fine and small.
I will be looking at modding it soon to be a 617SQN Dambuster replica.

BTW I do this purely for a bit of fun. If you like the model and feel like giving me a tip please just make a donation to your local kids hospital. Thanks for reading.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You will need to play with orientations that best suit your printer.
The wings and engines are printed vertically. You print the tails on their end plates. Do not use supporting inside the wing and tail keyways.
Depending on how accurate your printer is you may need to file down the keys on the main fuselage bits to fit into the wings and tails.
Using the original file I converted to solids and then proceeded to modify it so it slots together.

author: aleph37

description.text:
This is a part of a projection piece I did for my exhibition Occhiolism in 2015.
In the exhibition I used a projector to animate things like the eyes and it's
texture to give it more life and integrate it into the projections around it.
The print works well as a base for custom paint jobs or left blank as well.

The 3D model is quite high on poly count, so if you're running your printer
on a lower spec pc or just want to be able to print a larger one than your bed size.
You might want to use the split version that's in 6 parts.

Part name guide for the split version:
First letter corresponds to Upper, Middle, or Lower.
Second letter corresponds to Right or Left.
So
LL = Lower Left part of the print.
MR = Middle Right part of the print and so on.

Assembly tips (Optional but recommended for smoother end result)

After printing each part, sandpaper down unwanted bumps or artifacts.
Be careful to not sandpaper any surface near edges that will be glued to other parts.
After this, If you have a sheet of sandpaper, put it on a flat surface then place the side that will be glued on the sandpaper and gently sandpaper down just a tiny bit to get a strong connection for the glue. Do this on all sides that will be glued. (this also helps hide the edge where parts connect once assembled)

When gluing parts together, place them down on a flat surface, add the glue to one of the parts then push them together. This is to keep things aligned so no part will jut outwards.

After it's all glued together, sand down the rest of the print until it's as smooth as you want.

At this point I personally like to spend extra time to get my prints as smooth and nice looking as I can, so spending a few extra days on this segment is a no-brainer for me. But I understand if people will skip this step as it is very tedious.
What I like to do is apply a few layers of Filler spray and once dried sandpaper it down and repeat until it's smooth enough. This can take up to a week, so if you're low on time and have excessive amounts of sand paper, you can paint on acrylic paint, hair dry it and then sandpaper it down. Be careful and use pretty fine paper and you shouldn't risk ripping the paint off once it's very thin.

Once that's done, spray paint the print!
I like to use thicker paint like Montana's 94 series with a pretty fat cap.
It makes it a quick process and it's easy to get an even layer of paint out in no time.

If you do use spray paint like that and can mix an acrylic paint in the same color.
A nice trick I figured out to get a nice finish. Apply a rough layer of acrylic paint over the spray paint, let it dry and with a decently fine sandpaper go over it just a bit. It will give the print a similar feel as Plaster but be as light as plastic.

Good luck!

I designed the dispenser to use a single m5x30 plate screw (see photo), and a matching wave spring washer.

If you don't want the snapping function, you can just trim off the tiny studs on top of the hole-plate. And simply tighten the screw down to your satisfaction.

I would also suggest you run a 6mm drill through each hole after printing, in order to clean up any strings and irregularities.

comments.author: LysolPionex

comments.text: I really like the design. I am printing one right now and looking forward to the end result. I am a huge fan of the 22LR and own several firearms in that caliber.  One suggestion I would give is that although there are benefits to having such a thick plate to hold the rounds, such as noise and vibration reduction, a thinner plate similar to some CCI and Browning packs would save a substantial amount of print time and material.
comments.author: Vaeloron

comments.text:
Yep, I was thinking the same when modelling the dispenser.
But in the end I went with a thicker plate to reduce the wobbling, and make them slide out easier if they have a slightly thicker bullet.
I've had bullets with tiny globs of wax on them, that made them stick slightly in normal holders (and when trying to slide out at an angle).
comments.author: Vaeloron

author: Hermes1229

description.text:
One of my bigger projects, this little bugger is made to be able to be scaled up and printed in life like size or in smaller parts to fit nicely on a desk or shelf.
The model in the picture was printed with each "cube grid" being 20x20x20mm.

Assembly tips (Optional but recommended for smoother end result)

After printing each part, sandpaper down unwanted bumps or artifacts.
Be careful to not sandpaper any surface near edges that will be glued to other parts.
After this, If you have a sheet of sandpaper, put it on a flat surface then place the side that will be glued on the sandpaper and gently sandpaper down just a tiny bit to get a strong connection for the glue. Do this on all sides that will be glued. (this also helps hide the edge where parts connect once assembled)

When gluing parts together, place them down on a flat surface, add the glue to one of the parts then push them together. This is to keep things aligned so no part will jut outwards.

After it's all glued together, sand down the rest of the print until it's as smooth as you want.

At this point I personally like to spend extra time to get my prints as smooth and nice looking as I can, so spending a few extra days on this segment is a no-brainer for me. But I understand if people will skip this step as it is very tedious.
What I like to do is apply a few layers of Filler spray and once dried sandpaper it down and repeat until it's smooth enough. This can take up to a week, so if you're low on time and have excessive amounts of sand paper, you can paint on acrylic paint, hair dry it and then sandpaper it down. Be careful and use pretty fine paper and you shouldn't risk ripping the paint off once it's very thin.

Once that's done, spray paint the print!
I like to use thicker paint like Montana's 94 series with a pretty fat cap.
It makes it a quick process and it's easy to get an even layer of paint out in no time.

If you do use spray paint like that and can mix an acrylic paint in the same color.
A nice trick I figured out to get a nice finish. Apply a rough layer of acrylic paint over the spray paint, let it dry and with a decently fine sandpaper go over it just a bit. It will give the print a similar feel as Plaster but be as light as plastic.

Good luck!

author: Gockelmann

description.text: Bench and table for garden railway size 1:24

So I decided to build myself a relatively cheap workbench using Ikea's Antonius line of furniture. I saw that they had a nice little rack system for drawers, a 4 ft table top, and a set of legs and I thought Perfect! Bought two sets of everything planning to make an 8ft bench with lots of storage underneath.
When I got them home to assemble them, lo and behold even though they were from the same system they were not designed to play nice together or at least the way I wanted them to.
The shelf units were designed to only work with the short top that only covers the top of the unit. The legs were designed to work with the table top but were designed to work with a wall mount system that I was unable/unwilling to use.
My answer was to drill out the holes needed to attach the bases and screw them down. Then print off these adapters to allow the legs to be attached anywhere you want them. There is two sets of holes in each leg for attaching the wall mount leg section so I appropriated them to attach this adapter. You can use one or both. I included both for strength. The adapter needs to be attached to the underside of the table top before attaching the leg.
I just got my Prusa finished so haven't had a chance to print these off yet but they should work. There is two versions. One with a flange so it can be screwed down with 4 screws and one with a single screw hole in the center of the adapter. I wasn't really sure which one would be best. Will print and test them both when I can.

Needed per 4ft bench:
2x Printed adapters
1x Antonius Frame -101.776.30- $10
1x 4ft Antonius counter top -001.048.18- $20
1x pack Antonius adjustable legs -101.909.76- $15
Drawers of your choice -Various- For the drawers I went with 2 wire drawers and 1 deep plastic drawer. If you use the shallow plastic drawers you can have a total of 4 drawers but I wanted the deep ones. Measure the spacing for the holes on the frame and drill accordingly.
Attach adapters at your choice of location at other end of counter top.
Screw counter top to base and attach legs to adapters.
Use nice new bench! Personally I created a mirror image of this set up so I had nearly 4 feet of open space in the middle broken only by the legs with racks for storage at each end.

This was designed to hold my watches as I have one for work and one for fashion. Could be used for bracelets and necklaces too. Mounted to inside of closet with thumb tacks.

*Printed it out on the side with %15 support for the arm. Came out real nice.
V2 has knobs on the ends to keep the watches from sliding off.

My spool holder with filament guide broke, so instead of printing a new one I just made a model of only the filament guide. It's held together with a 4 mm screw and have holes for the screw head and square nut. I had these laying around from an old meccano set and it worked out nicely. For extra grip I put a little bit of tape on the inside of the clamp part.

Printer: Printrbot Simple Metal w/ heated bed.
Printed with PLA on 200 degrees.

title: Lasercut Camouflage & Insignia Airbrush Templates
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
File updated 12AUG2017 2030EST with US and Commonwealth insignia as well as two new variants of strip camouflage which should be suitable for use between 10mm and 20mm scales.

Laser cut camouflage templates sized to easily acquired, durable and reusable Avery labels - design 22827. Oriented to landscape. I have yet to test these on a laser cutter, so you're own your own for now. Contains several camouflage patterns that could likely be resized and used at different scales, if you have the wherewithal to change them in whatever vector app that you are using? None of the patterns are official to any actual or fictional setting or era. I am likely to add more to these as my requirements expand. Red lines are cut lines, Grey lines are for reference only but should etch as rasters. Print at 300 DPI.

Store - https://www.staples.ca/en/Avery-White-Laser-Inkjet-Durable-Removable-Rectangular-Labels-4-3-4-x-3-1-2-32-Pack-22827/product_989743_1-CA_1_20001

Baseline template - https://www.avery.ca/downloadable-templates/labels/specialty-labels-templates/avery-removable-durable-rectangular-labels-22827-template-portrait.html

Formatted for cutting on letter sized 8.5" x 11" label sheets. I use an Epilog Helix. Template has been designed with ample safety margin around edge of their frames. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

And... as usual - If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

author: hsaturn

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

One of the bigger projects I've done, This one was also for the exhibition Occhiolism I did back in 2015.

This one requires some assembly, but gladly I modeled this one to make it as easy as possible.

Rescaling to preferred size required.
All .stl files are pretty large by default so I suggest you to rescale something like the Chest_F part, print it and see if you're happy with that size before printing all parts in that scale.

Assembly tips (Optional but recommended for smoother end result)

After printing each part, sandpaper down unwanted bumps or artifacts.
Be careful to not sandpaper any surface near edges that will be glued to other parts.
After this, If you have a sheet of sandpaper, put it on a flat surface then place the side that will be glued on the sandpaper and gently sandpaper down just a tiny bit to get a strong connection for the glue. Do this on all sides that will be glued. (this also helps hide the edge where parts connect once assembled)

When gluing parts together, place them down on a flat surface, add the glue to one of the parts then push them together. This is to keep things aligned so no part will jut outwards.

After it's all glued together, sand down the rest of the print until it's as smooth as you want.

At this point I personally like to spend extra time to get my prints as smooth and nice looking as I can, so spending a few extra days on this segment is a no-brainer for me. But I understand if people will skip this step as it is very tedious.
What I like to do is apply a few layers of Filler spray and once dried sandpaper it down and repeat until it's smooth enough. This can take up to a week, so if you're low on time and have excessive amounts of sand paper, you can paint on acrylic paint, hair dry it and then sandpaper it down. Be careful and use pretty fine paper and you shouldn't risk ripping the paint off once it's very thin.

Once that's done, spray paint the print!
I like to use thicker paint like Montana's 94 series with a pretty fat cap.
It makes it a quick process and it's easy to get an even layer of paint out in no time.

If you do use spray paint like that and can mix an acrylic paint in the same color.
A nice trick I figured out to get a nice finish. Apply a rough layer of acrylic paint over the spray paint, let it dry and with a decently fine sandpaper go over it just a bit. It will give the print a similar feel as Plaster but be as light as plastic.

Good luck!

description.text:
This is a basic poker chip for dual extrusion printing, in classic 39 mm diameter size (3.3 mm thick). If you want it to have the same size as the usual cheap Chinese stuff, scale up to 102.56% for 40 mm diameter.

I mainly created this to have a more interesting and stylish test piece for testing and calibrating my dual extrusion setup. Now every not entirely failed test print contributes to my stash!
This print is particularly good at revealing misalignment of multi-extruder setups. Check for gaps between the main body and inlays, and check that the six outer notches are flush with the edge of the chip.

title: CR-10 Fan Duct Mod w/Thicker Bolt Standoffs

description.text:
This is a remixed version of the fan duct mod published here by Nexi-Tech.

I increased the thickness of the bolt stand-offs as I was finding the originals to be a bit too thin and would easily break due to accidental over tightening of the mounting bolts (the stock fan duct suffers the same issue). This is a far more robust design and the stock bolts are plenty long enough to accommodate.

description.text: VAZ logo in AUDI style.

print_settings.Notes:: See below for helpful printing and assembly tips.

description.text:
Yogi Bear, from the cartoon series by Hanna-Barbera.

Yogi is from Jellystone Park and his most popular saying is "I'm smarter than the av-er-age bear!", although he often overestimates his own cleverness.

No supports are required. If you have the proper filament colors, no painting is needed.

The model is 200mm tall.

Enjoy, and don't forget to bring along your own "pic-a-nic basket" like Yogi.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

See below for helpful printing and assembly tips.

Colors (there are no multiple printed pieces)

Dark brown:
arm_left
arm_right
head
body
..
Green:
base
hat_bottom
hat_top
tie
..
Gold:
basket
basket_handle
..
Black:
nose
hat_middle
eye_blacks
sign_letters (purposely upside down, see notes)
..
White:
collar
eye_whites
..
Beige/skin:
face
..
Light brown:
sign
..
Any color (hidden pieces)
pins (contains two pins)

Printing and assembly tips

Printing tips
1-As with most of my models, no supports are required.

2-Be sure to clean any first layer squish if you have any problem joining parts. The parts should fit nicely when printed cleanly.

3-I did not require any rafts or brims for any of the parts, except for the main body. It's the largest piece and has a small 'footprint' so I used a brim as a precaution.

4-I purposely have the words for the sign positioned to print upside down. I've found that for accuracy, the top layers of a printed part are more consistent in size than the very bottom layer (no matter how well leveled you plate is). This way the flat side from the printer bed becomes the side that you see and the top layers of the letters get pressed into the sign. Simply flip the words stl if you do not agree, and print them normally.

..
Assembly tips:
1-There are only two pins required, one for each arm. I originally planned for a pin in the hat but determined that the hat fit better without the pin. Ignore the hole for the pin.
2-The left and right eye_whites are not the same, use the top of each eye_white piece to match the slight curve of the hat.
3-Glue the basket_handle to the basket only. Attach the basket to the hand simply by tilting the basket into the hand. No gluing is required and the basket can swing a bit.
4-Each letter is put into the sign individually as per the above explanation.
5-Refer to the assembly diagram for putting the model together. The model is meant to be glued.

Yogi Bear assembly diagram

comments.text:
You, Mr Solomon, are a genius. Your designs are superb, and they assemble with precision and accuracy. I've done all the Flintstones, Wallace and Gromit, and the Pickles. This model of Yogi Bear is faultless.
However, I've got to tell you that you have quite ruined 3D printing for me. There I was, printing out monochromatic models for two years, and as happy as can be. Then I discovered your incredible multi-colour designs. How can I go back to boring one filament models now? I can't..... Besides, I've nearly forgotten what supports are for.....
This, of course, puts you under a deep moral obligation to keep the models coming for me, and people like me, who have had their printing standards raised to new heights!
I have a little knowledge of 3D design, but I have no idea how you make these models. As I said before, genius.
Very many thanks for all your efforts. Truly very much appreciated.
Trevor.
PS I'll put photos of my prints onto the appropriate pages in the next few days.

I will call these Corner Clips...

Now improved so the thumb screws will not dig into the bottom of the heatbed. I added small disks to interface between the screws and the heatbed. They are attached with their own little supports integrated into the design.

This thing is my idea for glass clips for use with the mirrors from Home Depot. The mirrors I purchased were 3.8mm thick. I use three of them and place them in the corners that do not have the heat bed wires. The Corner Clips have been updated to fit correctly and the screw holes are the correct size. They have been further updated to hold the glass down to the bed to prevent warping. These really work a treat and I feel are so much better than the spring clips that came with the machine. For strength I print these flat on the diagonal surface without supports. because I thickened up the design a bit, I no longer use a brim when printing them. I do use purple glue stick on the mirror though. I printed these in ABS and scaled them up 4%. It might be possible to print these in PETG but I have not had the opportunity to try, they work so amazingly well in ABS.

To use these you will want to purchase the 12x12x.1 inch mirrors from Home Depot. While you are there go to the hardware section and find the half inch long 10-24 thumb screws they sell there and buy two packs. I originally designed Corner Clips to use 10-24 set screw 5/16in long, however these clips need to be adjusted when the bed is warm and needing a tool to make those adjustments was completely impractical. Using the thumb screws makes Corner Clips a pleasure to use.

Notice: It has been brought to my attention that Home Depot in other markets sell mirrors in thicknesses other than the one i use and designed my Corner Clips for. If you have a mirror in another thickness other than 3.8mm and want this design to work I will be happy to make the adjustment.

title: 8 legged spider robot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The goal of this robot was to keep it as simple as possible but remain the most important movements. This robot uses 4 micro servo's salvaged from old and broken indoor rc-planes and helicopters. these servo's are controlled by an arduino nano and powered by two 1 cell 200mAh lipo battery's. To control the movement of the robot I use a Bluetooth transeiver connected with an android device. This allows me to make the robot go forwards, backwards, turn left and turn right.

more info about this project can be found here : https://hackaday.io/project/26049-8-legged-spider-robot

video of this robot walking can be found here : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hj8gsWjy_DY&t=68s

If you like my video leave a thumbs up and if you want to see all my video's and my future video's consider subscribing, it is free, doesn’t take much time and you are really helping me out by doing this. Thank you in advance!

Feel free to take a look at my other designs:

description.text:
I wanted to try something different with the Toranado Gear Cover so I pulled a couple of files and remixed them to create this monstrosity.

It was originally intended to be rather smaller but I actually don't mind it so much and like watching it spin, especially during retraction.

I printed this at .8 resolution and it requires no supports.
Therefore you can pretty much print it at any resolution you prefer. The 20% infill is more than enough and keeps the weight down.

It uses the original Toranado Gear Cover file so all you need to do is remove your original gear cover and screw this one in it's place.

Love it or hate it, it is here for anyone that may want it.

This is specifically designed for the popular Jump Start brand of grow lights sold on Amazon in 2ft and 4ft configurations - although it may work on others, as this these lights are sometimes re-badged and sold under different brand names.

The plastic connectors that ship with these lights are hollow, thin walled, and easily broken, and replacement parts aren't very easy to come by.

I designed a replacement that is still hollow, for fast printing, but utilizes round, hollow cavities and thicker walls for added strength.

title: Feed Drive Gear Singer Sewing Machine

description.text:
A friend of mine found out one day that the feed dog for her old Singer sewing machine stopped moving. The feed dog is the part of the sewing machine that pulls of the fabric while you're sewing so you get a distinct stitch length however you have it set.

It turned out that the feed drive gear had crumbled to pieces inside the machine. This part was meant to turn the feed drive shaft gear which moved the feed dog. Also no one online seemed to sell the part as the model of machine was so old.

So I modeled off a new gear using the pieces of the old gear that survived and printed a new one. The gear is meant to fit on a metal piece that secures it to the rotating shaft. I just used a mallet and hammered it in place since the gear is meant to take a lot of stress anyway.

It was designed to fit a model 4552 Singer Sewing machine but may also be compatible for the following models of Singer machines as well: 4600, 4610, 4613, 4617, 4622, 4623, 4624, 6230, 6233, 6234, 6235, 6267, 6268, 7000, 7004, 7005, 9005, 9008, 9010, 9410, 9416, 9417, 9430

How to replace gear:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qHx6VPdenj0

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

30%-50%

Notes:

The gear is fairly small so not to much infill is needed.
This was printed in ABS.

title: Foot Rest for IKEA ANTILOP High Chair

description.text:
The lack of a foot rest is really the only issue with the well-known IKEA ANTILOP baby high chair. We found several ideas online on how to add a foot rest, but none that satisfied us, so I designed this part.

You need to print the left and right part, and then you'll need a piece of plastic or wood for the actual foot rest. I used a section of cable duct I had left over from another project. I cut it to 37 cm, which allows a placement up to about 46 cm from the floor. I drilled holes for the screws 1 cm from the edges, and I glued the screws to the plastic with Araldit (epoxy glue). Thanks to the long holes in the supporting parts, we'll be able to lower the foot rest as the baby grows. I used four M4x30 screws for the assembly.

All settings are parametric, including the angles and diameter of the feet, so you should be able to generate parts for other chairs too. Leave a comment here if you need assistance, as the OpenSCAD file doesn't contain much documentation...

title: NRA: We're Coming For You Democracy

description.text:
Are you a hunting/marksmanship group that got taken over by far-right conservatives in the late-1970s? Did a Democrat lose the Presidential election and Republicans control Congress? Then you'll need a new group to demonize before gun sales level out and you start losing memberships! Why not attack one of the core foundations of our democracy? The free press.

Required Reading:

  • NRA spokeswoman threatens New York Times in viral video: 'We're coming for you'
    (http://www.businessinsider.com/nra-dana-loesch-new-york-times-video-2017-8)
  • Why the NRA is going after the media (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2017/08/04/why-the-nra-is-going-after-the-media/)
  • How NRA’s true believers converted a marksmanship group into a mighty gun lobby
    (https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/how-nras-true-believers-converted-a-marksmanship-group-into-a-mighty-gun-lobby/2013/01/12/51c62288-59b9-11e2-88d0-c4cf65c3ad15_story.html)
  • Timeline of the NRA
    (https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/timeline-of-the-nra/2013/01/12/351bcb26-5b9c-11e2-beee-6e38f5215402_story.html?utm_term=.b5367ceef30b)

Selected Quotes On The Free Press:

  • "The liberty of the press is essential to the security of freedom in a state" - John Adams, Samuel Adams, James Bowdoin
  • "Our liberty depends on the freedom of the press, and that cannot be limited without being lost." - Thomas Jefferson

Disclaimer: I support legal gun ownership but there seems to be no low that the NRA won't stoop to in order to keep their membership up, even if it hurts or fractures our country.

title: Chevy Colorado Above Stereo Phone Mount

description.text:
This mount conforms to the dashboard and tray contours of the 2015 and above Chevy Colorado. There's room for double-sided tape on the back of the mount in the tray area and in the front of the mount on the stereo fascia - no need to stick anything to the leather. I'm using the iBolt mini ball mount: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01EVRS7P2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 but other amps compatible mounts should work as well.

I think the version of the tray with the Bose upgrade is a different size so this may or may not work with that model. Would love to hear feedback on the Bose fit.

author: HorizonLab

description.text:
All pieces are meant to be laid flat so that they are printed with the most strength possible. I've chamfered some bottom edges to make it easier to put together some of the piece as well. The holes on the front edge of the rear top plate are meant to hold the GPS and FPV antenna, the circle is the right size to fit a SMA connector while the other side planned to have another piece slide through and secured with a zip-tie to hold the GPS, however after making this one, I've decided to move those to another plate on the next version. The next version will likely have longer front arms, a thinner and shorter middle section, and a removable gimbal mount for storage and travel (for my model of gimbal, Tarot T4-3D, but hopefully can be adapted for others of similar size).

Printing guide:
Front Side Clip - 4x
Front Top and bottom half plate - 2x normal, 2x mirrored
Rear bottom plate - 1x
Rear top plate - 1x
Rear side - 2x
Rear corner - 2x
Landing gear side - 4x normal, 4x mirrored
Landing gear foot - 4x
Landing gear arm mount - 4x
Landing gear blocker - 4x
Motor top mount - 4x
15mm through mount - 4x

1x of each of the hole guides

Hardware:
25x 25mm m3 screws
17x m3 nuts
4x 20mm m3 screws
4x m3 thumb nuts

Carbon Fiber:
15x15 square tube:
Front arms - 2x 80mm
Back arms - 2x 130mm

10x10 quare tube:
Body sides - 2x 165mm
Body front - 1x 115mm
Body back - 1x 95mm
Landing gear - 4x 125mm

Using hole guides:
Front arms:
Use motor hole guides on one end of the tube, drilling both holes vertically
Use the Front Arm hole guide on the other end, drilling the first hole from the edge vertically, then the second hole horizontally
The resulting holes should go (starting from the motor hole end) vertical, vertical, horizontal, vertical, see picture for reference

Back arms:
Use motor hole guides on one end of the tube, drilling both holes vertically
Use the Rear Arm hole guide on the other end, drilling the first hole from the edge horizontally, then the second hole vertically
The resulting holes should go (starting from the motor hole end) vertical, vertical, vertical, horizontal, see picture for reference

Body front and back:
Use 10mm hole guide on both ends, drilling only the first hole from the edge vertically on both

Body front:
Drill a hole in the center vertically (I ended up using the top plate to line this one up)

Body sides:
Use 10mm hole guide on both ends, drilling only the first hole from the edge vertically on both
Use the second hole on the 10mm guide on only one end, drilling horizontally

Landing gear:
Use 10mm hole guide on one side, drilling only the girst hole from the edge vertically

Assembly:
The main things to note are that you will want to snap together any printed pieces before anything screws are secured and the landing gear are attached using the same screws that hold the motors in place. Any pieces that snap together are then sandwiched with screws, so putting in a screw first may mean disassembling something. Each of the pieces fit together as shown in the screenshots and pictures. The print was designed with very tight tolerances, so you may have tweak a little if your printer isn't very accurate for the pieces that snap together, but they're intended to be pretty secure when connected. I ended up using a rubber mallet on a few to get them together.

My recommendation is in the following order:
Snap together the front plate and clip pieces, then connect and secure in the 10mm front and side body tubes using 25mm screws
Snap together the rear plate, side, and corner pieces, then connect and secure the 10mm front and side body tubes using 25mm screws vertically and 20mm screws horizontally
Take each of the arms, you should have 1 horizontal set of holes in each. Drop a 15mm through mount into the arm, then get the hole lined up with the horizontal hole in the arm and screw a 20mm screw through until it is completely tight against the mount and one end is stick out of the arm not connected to anything (this will be used to secure the arms when unfolded).
Secure each of the arms, making sure the screws we just put through line up with the holes in the sides of the frame.
Now start on the landing gear; put the Motor top mount on the top and the Landing gear arm mount on the bottom of an arm, then start a 25mm screw through from the bottom. Once it starts poking out of the top mount, put a motor on and finish securing to that.
Once the mount is secured and fully tightened, then you can put on the landing gear sides and blocker, then secure a 10mm tube using a 25mm screw.
Landing gear feet can be put on at any time and are just pushed into place.

Landing gear stay in place just due to friction, so make sure those are well-secured. I don't yet have the thumb nuts to show the arms being secured, but should be easy enough to see what's intended; mine are currently just held in place with friction as well and seems to be more than enough anyways. Working on a new version, so sorry about the rushed instructions, but let me know if you have any questions on assembly.

This is a parametric pinch block designed in OpenSCAD.  It's intended use is as a mount for a steel bar, pipe, or bearing.  It can be used to mount ground steel rods as linear guides, as well as the brass sleeve bearings which ride on said rods.
Open in OpenSCAD, plug in parameters, export to STL, and print.

Update: After test printing this I see that there are zero-width surfaces that have no chance of printing correctly. Also, the ridge around the edges are too thin.

title: Heavy Duty E3D v6 Mount for Creality CR7 CR8 CR10

description.text:
Heavy duty E3D-v6 mounting bracket for the Creality CR-10. I designed this because the other ones just aren't solid enough. This one mounts using 3 screws, and clamps around the top of the plate for extra support. It also has a tie-wrap pillar for cable management.

This is also designed so the nozzle is roughly in the same place along the z axis as the stock hotend, so no need to mess around with the z home micro-switch, but you will still need to re-level your bed.

It also has 2 generic mounting points each side, that allows people to make custom parts such as probe mounts, cooling fans etc. There are stl and step files for the mating parts of the generic mounts provided. These mounts allow a vertical adjustment of roughly 4mm, and guide rails to keep them oriented correctly when screwed down. As you can see in the pictures, I have experimented with some awesome looking dual cooling fan mounts, but these were functionally quite terrible, so I have not included them. I have however included a left or right hand EZABL mount, although I do not an EZABL probe so I am just guessing at the size and position.

As a bare minimum, you will also need;

2x M3x30 screws
2x M3 nyloc nuts

You can reuse the existing screws from the stock hotend and fan cover, however as these are quite weak and easy to chew up the allen socket, I would recommend using some different screws, in which case you will also need;

2x M3x6 screws
1x M3x20 screws

If you plan on using the mounts either side, these will each require;

1x M3 nyloc nut
1xM3x12 screw

No supports needed, just print as already oriented in the stl's. As these need to be quite strong I recommend using roughly 70% infill and at least 3 perimeters.

Thanks for looking, hope it's useful!

comments.text: Hey @graham01, I love your design, I've been using this (and your fan duct) on my CR-10 for a few days now, and I love it more than a regular fang. My only bit of constructive criticism is the use of M3 screws to attach the collar brace to the gantry bracket. M3 screws in many places cost more than their larger variants, and (atleast in the U.S.) I can't find anyplace that sells M3 screws that are above x20. To combat this issue, I just got a drill out and made the holes 6-32 and used machine screws and bolts. If you're willing, I'd suggest changing the collar screws to M4s.

title: Lap Steel Guitar, vintage SciFi style. For 200mm and larger printers

description.text:
This is a fun instrument project although not a particularly easy one (depending on your skill level). Print time for all 54 parts is around 70 hours, using 2kg of various color PLA.
This was made in 123D design, the original file is included so feel free to tweak, remix, and alter.

This will print on a 200x200mm printer. The printer will need to be tuned and calibrated very well, but quite a few parts will need to be filed or sanded in order to fit correctly.
It's highly suggested that you set the infill and layer angle to 0 or 90 degrees, which will make the top layers look much better on the assembled lapsteel. I did that for all parts but the fingerboard, you can see that's the only part that does not look all that great.

I used 1.5kg filament for the 4 main body sections. These parts have quite a bit of tension on them. Body4 in particular needs to be very strong with high infill otherwise the bridge will flex and you'll never get the instrument to stay in tune. I used PLA at a higher than normal temperature and less cooling on Body4 to maximize layer adhesion.

The wings can be printed with less infill as they do no bear any load.

Print the fingerboard and splines at 100% infill.

Items needed:
Set of 3x3 tuners
Set of P90 pickups
2 250k or 500k potentiometers
3 way Gibson style switch
1/4 mono jack
3' 1/4-20 threaded rod
1/4-20 nut and washer
200mm 1.4 to 2mm music wire or other hardened steel wire for string anchors
5mm metal rod for bridge and nut
Set of lap steel stings
Superglue
Epoxy

Not counting the filament, the hardware and supplies came to around $40, buying the cheapest I could find on Amazon.

About the part naming:
Assembly numbering: 1 nearest the tuners, higher numbers towards the bridge. Prefix B indicates Bass side (toward player), T is treble side.

Don't leave this in your car on a hot day!

title: Fully 3D-Printed Rubik's Cube Solving Robot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
https://youtu.be/P5tbpXMmv6A

This 3D-printed Raspberry Pi-powered Rubik’s Cube solving robot has everything any serious robot does -- arms, servos, gears, vision, artificial intelligence, and a task to complete. If you want to introduce robotics to your kids or your students, this is the perfect machine for it.

This one-eyed four-armed giant stands 35cm (14") tall. 70 hours of print time and an entire spool of filament are needed to print it, not to mention over $200 worth of hardware, but once fully operational, it will surely wow your friends and neighbors. Scramble your Rubik's cube, place it in the robot’s grippers, press a button, and then sit back and watch this amazingly smart and stunningly beautiful machine put it back together. Watch the video!

This robot is fully 3D-printable. Other that the servos, servo horns, camera, electronics and a few dozen bolts and nuts, it has no traditionally manufactured parts. Absolutely no soldering or breadboarding is required.

Total Print Time: 4,028 min. (67 hours 8 min.)
Total Filament at 20% infill: 882 gr.

For the list of hardware component, detailed assembly instructions and other important information, please visit our web site at http://www.otvinta.com/download12.html.

Update (2018-02-08):
If your 3D printer has a large enough print platform, print 2 of rcr_4corners.stl instead of 8 of rcr_corner.stl

Update (2018-02-08):
Version 2.0.80.0 (currently in beta) offers an auto configuration mode of operation. In this mode, the app does not need any configuring whatsoever. The colors of the center cubies are used as the samples for color recognition. The new version also performs automatic error correction. Another important enhancement is that instead of taking static photos, the app now shoots short videos and uses the last frame for analysis. This artificial delay in image capturing allows the camera to adjust to the current lighting conditions and produce more vivid, easier-to-analyze images.

Update (2018-01-23):
We have successfully tested the servo motor Towerpro MG996R to be used instead of the HS311 for the rack-and-pinion mechanisms. The MG996R is available at half the price of the HS311. Use rcr_pinion2.stl instead of rcr_pinion.stl with this servo.

Update (2017-12-11):
We have successfully tested a new, better, camera for this robot, and designed a new camera holder for it, rcr_camera_holder2.stl. The new "wide" camera is only a few dollars more expensive but has many advantages over the old round one: it has better color reproduction, works well in poor lighting conditions, does not have or need LEDs (which eliminates the glare problem), does not require a cover, and is easier to adjust. Please visit our site for more info.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/edit?o=U&video_id=q7crYSmn6Dk" ></iframe>
The only gear mechanism this robot employs is a rack-n-pinion to provide linear motion to its arms. This tutorial, created by us, explains how to quickly design a rack-n-pinion mechanism is Blender.

comments.text: You can do a fair amount of filing, or as I did you can cheat, unscrew the four screws on the back of the DS3218 so the back plate loosens, then it is easy to push the plate through (with the cable) then put the rest of the motor back on and re-insert the very long bolts. comments.text:
I'm curious what settings to use to get the print times on the details screen without loosing quality. For example, I have loaded rcr_arm.stl in both Cura and Simplify3D with 0.2mm layer and 20% fill and Cura is telling me it's going to take around 5 hours and 28 minutes while Simplify3D is telling me 4 hours and 45 minutes. I'm more familiar with Simplify3D, so here are some of the basic settings I'm using:
Layer Height: 0.2 mm
Top and Bottom Solid Layers : 3
Side Layers: 2
Infill: 20%
Support Pillar Resolution: 4 mm
Support Infill Percentage: 20%
Default Printing Speed: 60 mm/s
I currently have "Adjust printing speed for layers below..." disabled.
Any suggestions would be great. I have a Wilson II Reprap printer.
comments.author: cruce

comments.text: The numbers in that table were produced by Simplify3D, they are not the actual time measurements, and therefore approximate. It has been my observation that the time estimates Simplify3D generates tend to be too optimistic. I don't know exactly how it computes print time, but possibly it takes the 3D printer's make and model into account. Since we use different printers, the times are also different..

description.text: Type 98 Ke-Ni - 1:72

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:330253

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

No

0.2

15%
T-800 endoskeleton model

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Duplicator 6

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15 - 0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

This model should be printed by parts. And there are many.

!!!HOW TO SPLIT THE MESH!!!

Download and install Blender(its free)
TOP LEFT click File > Import > .stl
Select the mesh > TAB(edit mode) > Move cursor to a needed part of a mesh and press L
After part is selected press P > In separate window choose separate
press TAB to move out of edit mod > select the separated object
click File > export > .stl
In export screen on the left panel scroll down and choose SELECTION ONLY > Export STL
Repeat on each part.

The parts are different sizes and forms so you need to use settings accordingly.
Big ones 0.15 layer
And small ones like tubes wires and fingers 0.2

Painting

Each part must be painted and attached individually. To avoid detail loss.
Painting
1 coat of filler, sandbrushing
2 coats of glossy paint
1 coat of chrome paint

Extra optional: There is some electronics and wiring in my final model. So there are slots and places for that.

Electronics

Just go to the local store and buy 2 cheap solar lamps for the garden. Solar battery should be in size of 3cm. disassembe them. If you are familliar with this you will understand the rest by your self.
Eye diode is wired trough the right leg.

description.text:
Just a small model to test XY compensation settings for slicer programs.

The part has a 3mm diameter hole for an M3 screw, a 15mm diameter hole if you have a spare LM8UU bearing, and a 2mm wide slot and a 2mm wide square that should fit together.

Should be fairly simple to use. If the parts won't fit together or are too tight, lower the XY scale setting in your slicer settings. If the parts are too loose, increase your XY scale setting.

title: Batsignal (From movie: The Dark Knight Rises, 2012)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE: Due to popular demand, a PDF file containing the basic assembly instructions and wiring have been uploaded. Plase feel free to take a look at it and ask for any detail not included.
Also, U, V and W files have been included despite they have not been printed before.

NOTE: This has been a long project and it has suffered from several modifications. Please refer to Print Settings for more details.

The model represents the Batsignal as seen in the original movie "The Dark Knight Rises" from 2012.
It has been modelled at a 1:8 scale approximately according to Batman height estimations, nevertheless it can probably be scaled up. Scaling it down will probably need severe post printing modifications.

If you like the model, please take a second to consider tiping the creator, just on the left side of your screen. Modelling and preparation for 3d printing took around 20 hours. Just the 3d printing itself took around 65 hours, and sanding, painting and weathering have taken countless hours of work, I'd say more than 100 easily. Take a look again at the pictures and leave a comment about what you think, tip through Thingiverse (you just need a Paypal acount), or check my patreon if you feel amazed by the quality of the model.
Do you want a copy of the blueprint, just let me know by private message! It makes the perfect partner for the 3d printed Batsignal.

Several non-printed elements have been used:

  • 1x MicroUSB female terminal.
  • 1x 3.3V voltage regulator.
  • 1x 1W LED + Aluminum heat sink.
  • 1mm cable for wiring, aproximately 30 cm (12 inches).
  • 12x M3 screws with different lenghts.
  • 14x M3 nuts.
  • 2x M6 bolts for attaching the frame to the base.
  • A ton of M2 screws with half round head and hex socket.
  • 1x 3 pin slide switch.
  • Transparent 400 micron acetate sheet.

All these components can be bought in several places as well as in Aliexpress with international shipping. I think there is no need to include a scheme of the wiring because it's pretty straightforward. As an alternative, the electric box was designed to fit a 3xAAA battery holder. The decision to use USB of batteries is up to you!

I will include more details as questions appear in the comments, otherwise I think there is not too much to say.
Thank you for passing by, print it and enjoy.
The first one to get a picture on a foggy night with the batsignal will get a token from me ;)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15-20%

Notes:

Modelling and printing has take more than 6 months and during that time, some of the pieces has suffered from pre- and post-printing modifications. Therefore there is a chance that some pieces doesn't contain all final details or they need to be adjusted afterwards.
Supports has been custom created into some of the pieces and most of other files doesn't need them, nevertheless each piece is different so different criteria could apply for different printers.
Pieces A and B has been splitted into 4 pieces each to fit in standard FDM printers, as they are just over 20x20 cm. In case you want to print them in one piece, just ask for them, as it's very easy to export them again.
I printed completely in ABS but I see no reason why it should be printed in other materials.

This replica has been designed from the original movie taking as reference the movie itself as well as pictures from the batsignal dispersed all over the internet. Despite it has been completely modelled from scratch, if Warner Bros. Pictures or any other person/company owns the trademark for Batman series and feel that this model violate their rights, please contact me personally and I will be happy to remove it from the website.

comments.text:
Hi CrashcupMN, first things first, thanks for your words, but I did nothing no one else is able to do with some patience and time, so good luck with it. Can't wait to see other peoples creations, it's a very satisfying feeling to see other people from around the globe enjoy and build the same model I created in my own computer. Mind-blowing!
Lets move to your points. As you said, the bottom section I supossed it to be concrete, and sincerely is the part I'm most dissapointed with. Almost the rest of the model is old rusty steel, iron, or whatever metal it could be. I didn't use any special color tone. I painted all parts with graphite grey, with standard spray paint, and then applied several layers of acrylic paints, black for dirt, white and silver for highlights, brown, orange and yellow for rusty trails, and some shades of green in the concrete to simulate some kind of this typical fungus growing in porous surfaces. Not really specific colors, just the ones that came with my 20 colors kit.
For the technique, after the graphite base, I applied the rest of the colors with dry brush techniques or similar. For the black on steel, I diluted the paint slightly with water and after applying, I removed the excess and a little bit more with and old sock until I reached the desired tone, no more secret than that. If you don't have any experience, I suggest you to try first in a failed print, probably you have some around. It is exactly what I did before starting. For all screws, I painted them in advance with brown and applied some orange highlights for rust. Easy peasy. Screw them in a piece of cardboard and paint all of them at a time, so all of them they look almost the same.
For the reflector, just glossy grey acrylic paint (from the cheap kit as well) and several coats of glossy spray finish.
For the heatsinks, I bought these ones (2 pin ones):
http://s.aliexpress.com/QZVNzA3i?
And the LEDs look that the ones I bought are not available anymore, but just look for 1W SMD LED, they are round with opposed terminals. Small, powerful and cheap.

comments.text:
Thanks so much for this Arquit3d. This is not only a cool idea/design but also the most professional set of files, instruction and photos that I have seen on Thingiverse.
For everyone else who is posting criticism and trying to get Arquit3D to modify files to suit you... Part of 3D printing is trial and error and modifying the files to suit your needs and your printer. The projects on Thingiverse are just a base to get you started. If a part is too small/too big try scaling it and printing again or sanding or using some different print settings. It is not the responsibility of the uploader to make it work perfectly for you. They have just made a project that they thought would be worth sharing with everyone. Just be grateful for what has been provided and figure out how to get it working for yourself from there.

description.text:
I received a old Printrbot Plus thru a program where i will donating it to a local school when I'm done upgrading it, I noticed some z wobble in the lead screws so i decided to create this brace for them. The upgrade should hopefully eliminate banding, I have not tested it yet but it should work in theory.

Assembly: screws 4 x M3-P0.5 x 35 mm 4 x M3 nuts
threaded rod you can use 10mm-1.5 or a 3/8" either one will work, just cut to fit.

you can print this twice, or mirror it on your build plate. I mirrored it so it would look cleaner on my printer.

This is a P Clip for 20mm Conduit. It's designed to suit corrugated 20mm conduit (which actually seems to be about 21mm outside diameter), but should be suitable for rigid PVC tubing also. The internal diameter when printed is 22mm, which clamps down to 21mm when the screw is tightened.

It needs one countersunk screw for mounting (it would suit a 6g x 5/8" wood screw for example).

I printed this in PLA, and found it was flexible enough to push onto the conduit.

title: Guard for GE Ice Maker Bucket

description.text:
Update 12/26/17 I finally assembled the guard, see photo. The printed parts are a mix of two or more iterations and only the splint on the top of the guard remains the same as those uploaded. The print is sturdy and OK, but it looks terrible. The temp was high and the speed was too fast. There is a green glue-on piece in the front of the guard where the screw fastens it to the bin.
In the photo, you can see the original, part (in two pieces). I failed to notice that the mounting hole is not in the center of the piece of the original part. I designed the part from half of the original and never removed the bin during the summer when I printed the parts to double check them against the bin. The right side piece (the mirrored piece) is shorter than it should be by about 11-12 mm. You can adjust the Z scale factor to increase the size by that amount, and the whole assembly should be very close to the original size. There were several mm of clearance on each side of the bin in the original part. The center glue-on piece was widened to compensate for the width change. You should probably print the left side and fit-check it in the bin before printing the mirrored right side that needs an adjusted Z scale factor.

I'll add an update if there are any problems that show up in the future. I am not convinced that my choice of PLA was the right one for this part.
= = = = =

This is a replacement part for the plastic guard that fits on the top-front of the interior of the Ice Bucket in a GE refrigerator. The PN of the Bucket in my refrigerator is: WR17X11429. You can find them on eBay. I call this piece a Guard; I don't know what anybody else calls them or if they are available as a spare part.

The original part broke a long time ago, before I had any idea of its function. It turns out that it is needed to prevent the ice from jamming up at the front of the bin and prevent the bin from being opened.

Print one piece of the guard, and another that is a mirror or the original. Glue the pieces together with CA glue, using the splints to strengthen it and also provide the mounting screw hole at the front of the bucket. The splint with the hole touches the front surface of the Ice Bin where it is attached with a screw. It is glued on the outside of the V-shaped section.

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa I3 Dual w/ mods

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 mm or greater?

Infill:

finished part should be mostly solid

Notes:

I'll used a 0.4 mm nozzle and 2 perimeters, with 100% infill for maximum strength.

I printed it in PLA, since it is easier to glue and as strong or stronger than ABS. ABS might still be the preferred material since it is tougher than PLA and might handle the force of ice chuncks being bashed into it without breaking as PLA might.

To insure the slope surfaces print well without using support, DO NOT select "EXT Perimeters First" and DO select "Infill Before Perimeters". If the sloped surfaces do not print well, just sand them down, they are not important to the overall part.

My prints required a lot of sanding to get them to fit well into the ice bucket.

Sand the edges that will be glued so they are flat and a good fit before gluing and attaching the splints. Also sand the edges that overhang onto the front of the ice bucket so they fit tightly against the front surface of the bucket and the top sides are smooth.

I sanded the surfaces that join the two pieces by sandwiching a piece of sandpaper (held in a vice) between the two pieces and moving them against one another to get a good fit along the long joint.

I used a spring clip to hold the top splint in place while the glue hardened.
An easy way to attach the front mounting piece is to fasten it to the bin with the screw, apply glue to the guard piece, position it against the front of the bin and hold in place while the glue sets.
Sketchup 2017

description.text: This is a gelatinous cube for a 28mm scale mini use. After frustrations of not finding an easy model to print with translucent material, I created a slime with a flat top. The sides are a bit jagged but it sure is easier to print.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

none

This pen is designed off of the .50 BMG cartridge.

This pen really is just a remix of ".50 cal BMG bullet and casing," I have given "50 cal Bullet Bic Pen adapter" credit for inspiration. When printing the original pen adapter, I had issues with it, an I wanted to fix them in my own design. Both the case, and the bullet have been modified.

I have created 2 versions of the pen tip, and case. The files starting with "SOLID" means that the majority of the part is 100% solid. The ones that are not named "SOLID" have minimal plastic in it.

The SOLID parts add a lot of mass to it, which makes it feel better.

The Pen Cap is held in place with friction.

What to print:
1x 50 BMG Pen Tip
1x 50 BMG Shell
1x Pen Cap

How to assemble:

  1. Insert 50 BMG Pen Tip into the 50 BMG Shell.
  2. Insert Bic Pen tip into 50 BMG Pen Tip.

Printer:

MPSM V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

100%

author: molotovec

description.text:
This handle will accommodate three dog leashes. Simple slip the loop end of the leash into one of the holes, then feed the clip end through the loop. When walking three dogs, rotate the handle as needed to untangle the leashes if they cross each other. It works great and is ideal for smaller dogs. I don't know if it will hold up to three strong dogs. Let me know in the comments if you try it and how heavy your dogs are.
I printed this at 40% fill with 3mm walls, no raft. Supports are recommended for the bottom round corners, although not absolutely necessary. I printed without supports and just scraped/sanded any imperfections.
I also realized I made it a little too large for my printer bed, so I reduced it by 15%. It is still a good size. I might consider resizing the original.

Doesn't Matter

40%

title: Fixation casquette de phare pour Derbi Senda

description.text:
Fixation prévue pour fourche de 36 mm de diamètre.
Ces pièces s'installent sur une moto Derbi Senda 50 cm3 de 2005. Il a peut être eu des évolutions selon les années (diamètre de fourche, type casquette de phare) ...

Le support inférieur est un peu plus court que le support supérieur, afin d'aligner correctement le phare.
Le serrage se fait avec vis + écrous M4.

Un petit trou est prévus pour glisser une petite goupille (fil de fer ou goupille "beta") afin de sécuriser la fixation. Ça tient sans mais il vaut en mettre.

Les fichiers DesignSpark Mechanical sont fournis. Les modifications sont faciles à faire (même principe que Sketchup mais en mieux !)

title: Nissan Note glovebox latch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are the spokes of the glovebox latch / lock for Nissan Note 2010. The parts that will snap from the lock if weight is put on the glovebox.

1) Unscrew the lock from the glovebox. 2) Use a screwdriver or similar push down the plastic pieces that keep the lock together and disassemble the lock mechanism until the spokes are free. 3) Remove the snapped spokes. 4) Replace with the printed ones. Note that there is a groove in the spoke hole and thus the two spokes are not interchangeable. 5) Reassemble the lock and screw it in place.6) Use the glove box. :)

title: E3D with Titan Extruder Cooling Fan and Part Fan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So I have been trying to get a part cooling fan that fit my setup and after so many iterations, I gave up and decided to build my own. I found a nice cooling fan mount for the E3D Heatsink (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:514141) and was using that for a while in the process of designing my own. I made a few upgrades to the heat sink fan mount. First, I made it a bit longer and removed the angle. Removing the angle made it easier to print without supports. I also added a few fins that will lock it in the same position with respect to the heat sink. Then I designed a part cooling unit that will hold a blower fan (https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B071XSLTQY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). This part basically snaps on to the heat sink fan mount and aligns flush with the Titan extruder cover.

If you look at the the pictures of the STL, you will see the orientation to print. With these orientations, the only support needed is for the part fan air flow path.

Please enjoy and thanks to SCHMIDDIM (https://www.thingiverse.com/schmiddim/about) for giving me a starting point.

EDIT: It was brought to my attention that this unit may inadvertently cause cooling issues on the hotend. The solution given was to use a silicone sock. I ran a quick test in Octoprint to monitor and temperature fluctuations and found none. I am not saying that a sock is a bad idea, but this cooling unit does not need one. Here is a link to the temperature monitor results: http://i.imgur.com/WLo5to7.png

author: Sam31

description.text:
This is a simple functionnal HDTV Antenna.

I used "100mm x 5M Pure Copper Foil EMI Single Side Conductive Guitar Shielding Tape" for the copper part. You can get that at ~10$ on banggood. Aluminium foil and glue stick will work as well, but will be a bit harder to cut right.

I suggest you cut off the small index pins if they don't work. Screw fit will be more than enough to keep everything straigt,

Use M3 screws that fits, I used M3x18.
You also need a 75 to 300 Ohm UHF/VHF Matching Transformer. Which you can get for a buck,

comments.text: Another way to add the conductive copper layer is via plating. I found out a few weeks ago that using conductive paint and brush plating solutions you can plate printed plastic. This would provide a consistent finish for something like this and would likely conduct more effectively but I can't be sure.

title: Heron's Fountain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a fully printable and working Heron's fountain, which is a fountain which isn't requiring a pump or something simmilar. See Wikipedia for a detailed description how it works: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heron's_fountain

Please note: This is not an easy print as it has to be water tight and even air tight as much as possible! You and your printer have to be able to produce high quality prints or you will end up wasting a lot of time with a non-functional fountain. One single gap will ruin the whole thing!

Short story

When I got my 3D printer, one of the very first things I designed and printed on it was a Heron's fountain. It was not comparable with this one now, it was about the size of one single tank from the current model and due to my not existing knowledge about the fine print things, it would only run for 1-2s with a 2mm "high" fountain.
It was a completely fail.

But I love printing functional things, and some days ago I stumbled about DKoss Heron's Fountain. This remembered me about my initial fail of a cool thing, and I thought about printing this one.
But after studying his design (which is not bad at all!) and with my experience in mind, I decided to create an own fountain design which should:

  • Not print all in one object: If something goes wrong, you will not see it, have no option to repair it and material and time is wasted.
  • Has as few access holes as possible. Each opening to fill / drain the water will add some possible leakage.
  • Looks good enough to have it standing around on the table.
  • Is easy to fill and drain again.

So I fired up Fusion 360 and ended up with this model of a Heron's fountain!

Printing and running the fountain

Please read the instructions below carefully before starting the print.
If you got it done, you should now own a Heron's fountain which runs for over 2 minutes with a quite high fountain with the default 1.5mm nozzle. You can also try other nozzle diameters and see how it changes runtime.

Here is a video of it running: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZctH1mX9gaI

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 recommended

Infill:

15% cubic or similar

Notes:

Be sure you extrusion is properly calibrated and your first layer height is nailed down to a realy good value.

I used 2 perimeters and 4 top/bottom solid layers. I recommend printing this at 0.15mm layer height, at least for areas with threads. Other areas might be printed at thicker heights, but keep in mind everything has to be water tight (and air tight as far as possible)!

Therefore also use a solid infill which creates seperated chambers in height and in plane as Slic3rs cubic infill. They will act like bulkheads if you have small leaks and prevent the hole print from filling with water over time.

The funnel and cup is meant to be printed in vase mode. I used 0.8mm extrusion width for stability.

Printing

Print one part after the other and carefuly inspect each one before going to the next one. This way you can adjust the slicer settings if something goes wrong without wasting many hours printing scrap.

Inspection

Inspect each parts for gaps between infill lines and perimeters. Especialy have an eye on the infill - perimeter intersection area. If you see any imperfections, adjust your print settings before going to the next part.
You can test pipe sections by blocking one end with your finger, blowing inside the other end.

You can repair small defects by placing a little drop of super glue on the point where necessary and wipe it into the void (and smoothing it by the way) with a tiny sheet of paper. The paper is meant to protect your fingers from the super glue, don't leave it inside the print!

Assembly

Place a sheet of sand paper on a flat surface and sand the interfacing faces a little bit to form good joints. Be careful when doing this on the middle tank, you don't want to break the pipe which has the same height level as the wall!

Use a realy thin, but even coat of epoxy resin to glue the parts together. Be careful to respect the parts orientation, always have a look from top to bottom to see if the pipes are coincident.
Start with glue the bottom plate to the lower tank. When the glue is dried, glue the bottom plate of the middle tank to the tank itself.
Next is a little bit more complicated, glue the two tanks together. Be very careful the hole for the nozzle and the square air channel line up between the two parts. You can look at the lines between the "bricks", if they line up nicely the holes will also line up.
As a last thing, glue the bowl to the tank tower. Orientate it the right way, the holes will only line up in one orientation!

To make the cap and nozzle as airtight as possible, I recommend cutting some rubber peace (old bicycle tube for example) so it fits inside the cap as a seal. You can also use two 10x1.5mm O-rings as I did.

Let it run!

Using a water proof pencil, make a mark 15mm below the top edge of the cup. This will result in ~460mL of water which is what you want fill in the middle tank.
Unscrew the cap, insert the funnel and slowly fill the water into the middle tank. Screw the cap in place again, don't forget to insert the o-ring.

Now it's ready to run - at least when you print and assembled everything in proper quality ;-)
Fill some water inside the upper bowl until the fountain is starting. If it's not realy starting or only sprinkling a little bit, their might be air bubbles trapped in the channel where the water goes down. Take a long, thin thing like a needle used for checking if a cake is ready in the oven and get them out by sticking it in the bore.

When the fountain stops, nearly all the water is inside the lower tank. For storing the fountain or restarting it, you have to remove it first. Just unscrew the cap and turn the fountain upside down.

This is a collection of trays for the 2015 and above Chevy Colorado. There are very few (no?) commercial trays custom to the Colorado and since the Colorado does not have a sunken ridge most generic trays interfere with the closure of the lid. These pieces fit either the rounded top lip or friction-fit the tapered sides of the bin.

These are all works-in-progress with more variations in the works.

This is a 2 inch miniature wall spike trap. It has four components. Nonfunctioning gears are on the side of the base and a wall with holes. There is a slide with spikes that can be moved in and out relative to the front face with a stone wall. Also there is a nonfunctioning handle at the back as if this activates the sliding spikes or sliding rear door. I have also provided the face of the spike trap with and without holes so that you could set up a game with faces that are not traps and then the face with barely noticeable holes until the spikes emerge.
You can also face the spikes inward and have the characters enter from the door at the rear. Then close the rear door and they are trapped with spikes coming towards them. Your choice of victimization.
Also I haven't glued the front face to the body yet so when I took the picture it appears that the face doesn't line up with the body, but this is not the case. When I put them down I allowed the face to move and didn't catch it until after I took the pictures.

title: Prusa I3 Rework BODY-EXTRUDEUR-WADE-1.75mm for E3D-V6
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After having to replace my real J-Head with an E3D-V6 clone I had to redo the extruder portion since the real J-Head is smaller and used a completely different approach.

The approach I used was to use some PTFE tubing shoved into the hotend all the way into the extruder where it butts up against the 2mm filament hole. This worked flawlessly but if you ever have to remove the hotend (which will rarely, if ever, be done in reality) it will demand the removal of the heater block then grab the PTFE tube and pull it out. Once that is done then simply unscrew the clip and slide the hotend out. No big deal and if I ever go to some exotic rubber like filament I can drill out the 4mm hole all the way then make the filament tube go all the way up and a cutout right before, and after, the bearings so the travel path will be short.

With the advent of Simplify3D I found that its supports were better than the built in/baked in supports I was using and is in the original I3 rework files.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30%

title: Anet A6 Z Synchronization and Bed Calibrator

description.text:
Making sure that the carriage rails are parallel to the bed is essential to good printing. Making sure that the Z blocks are properly aligned is the imperative before leveling the bed. I have always used calipers, but found it somewhat awkward to make the measurements accurately. I designed the bridge to span the horizontal rails and hold the calipers in a fixed position. I have dedicated a 100mm carbon fiber caliper (<$3.50 from AliExpress) to this alignment gauge.

Basically to use the gauge, I set it to MM (highest resolution) and mount it on the rails next to the left hand Z block and measure down to the Z stepper motor mount. I then zero the caliper and move it to the right side and repeat the measurement. The reading then tells me how much I need to manually step the right side motor to level the rails to the printer. If the reading is negative, the right side needs to be lowered and raised if positive. I repeat the procedure several times until I get a right side reading of zero.

Once the rails are horizontal, the gauge can be used to level the bed. Just calibrate one corner using the paper shim method and then use the gauge to measure down to that corner of the table and zero. By either moving the gauge on the rails or the table fore and aft, you can measure the relative height of all four corners. If the reading at the next corner is positive, the adjustment screw needs to be turned clockwise and counter clockwise if the reading is negative. Repeating the whole procedure should lead to further refinements. This should get the table level within +/- .05mm (.002”)

Note that the calipers I used have 3 buttons below the display, but the other common model with the MM / INCH button above the display will work as well.

title: Raspberry Pi CS lens mount adapter

description.text:
I needed a C/CS mount adapter to fit a 180x microscope lens to my Pi Camera board (v1.3) and rather than buy a whole new module with the mount for £20 or so, I decided I'd make an adapter.

I've not printed or tested this fits yet. I've also not made the inner M12x0.5 hole threaded yet, its just a 12mm diameter hole for now, but that's an extra function, I just want a CS mount for my Pi.

It uses the threads library so won't work as a Customizer, but you can download the scad file and the library and use it in OpenSCAD.

It attaches using two M2 holes to match those on the camera module, you will probably need to add a thread with a tap or use self-tapping screws.

Also now integrated into my Pi ZeroW case: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2151924

Also added a related item - a bracket to attach my 50mm diameter lens to my desk lamp.

description.text:
Updated lid 8/10/17, see bottom of summary
Box for storing the settlement, cities and roads for Catan (aka "Settlers of Catan")

The box is minimized as much as possible and pieces fit tightly. See 2nd and 3rd photo for the pieces in the box. The cities are laid down sideways.

The edge is inner edge is beveled as is the lid.
The lid slides into the box.

Printing the lid about 1% larger makes for a tighter fit.
*** Updated lids - see bottom of summary

Two types of lids are available with or without the Catan logo.

*** Update: New lids
Two new files for the lids called "catan_box_lid_fullsize.stl" & "catan_box_lid_plain_fullsize.stl".

These lids are full size, meaning they are designed with subtraction of the box. So far they fit nice (I found my original too loose). May need to shrink slightly. These lids are actually smaller than doing 0.5% enlargement of the original lids.

description.text: I used the cell phone stand created by na427 as a basis for this dual position cell phone stand. I liked the shape of the stand that na427 created. I did however need to cut about 5 mm off of the front lip because it was blocking my screen slightly in the horizontal position.

Printer:

Rafts:

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Post Printing

I didn't need to do anything but the slots might need to be cleaned out. My middle slots were slightly too tight at first but they worked in.

Design

I used Tinker CAD to cut down the height of the stand to 5 mm. I then added a 2.5 mm foot to the front bottom side of the profile. I duplicated the shape. I then made a base to hold the two stand profiles. The intention of my design was to be able to disassemble the stand and put it in a small case for travelling. I made the base 5 mm tall, 10 mm wide and 110 mm long. I then created 5 mm wide and 2.5 mm slots 50 mm apart and centered on the base. I also made slots approximately 100 mm apart and centered on the base. These slots allow me to place the holder profiles in the center for a vertical positioning of the phone and the outer slots for a horizontal positioning of the phone.
