title: Plastic Monstrosity -- The 3D Printed CNC for 4x8' Plywood
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my massive CNC capable of cutting a full 4x8 sheet of plywood with room to spare!
Stay tuned for build instructions and videos..

Update 2018-01-13
Added an 80mm spindle Z axis piece.

Update 2017-12-03
I fixed the print orientation for the gantry parts and the endcap. Remember to enable supports on the gantry.

Update 2017-12-01
If you're having trouble with slight variations in plywood height, I have created a simple Z probe that you can use in conjunction with bed height autocorrection (I'm using Smoothieware, so I have it do the height probing and correction in the firmware).
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2685926

Sorry for the lack of updates. I still don't have a BoM ready, much less a build guide. I've had a lot of other projects going on, and this is all just a hobby for me at the moment, so the amount of time I can allot for it is pretty minimal. Maybe I'll try to sell kits or something in the future -- if you'd be interested in such a thing, let me know.

Update 2017-11-04
Added guardPlate.stl. Reduce the belt bearings on the short axis to 2 per side (4 total) and place the guardPlate.stl piece along with a 1mm spacer. This prevents the belt from twisting.

Also added a picture of a full chair from OpenDesk cut in a single session. I'm marking the build complete, but will add more documentation in the future.

Update 2017-09-20
I added the following:

  • Makita compact router mount Z axis (makita.stl)
  • DWP-611 mount Z axis (dwp611.stl) - untested
  • pieces optimized for 60.3mm OD conduit (50NB)

Update 2017-08-21
Added components for the short axis belt for use with motors that have a shorter shaft. The belts are closer to the motor, but the new end supports take up an additional 30mm on the short axis.

comments.text: I used a 0.5mm nozzle, printing PETG at 255C with 3 perimeters and 4 top/bottom layers.  There's a trade-off to be made on PETG vs PLA..  PLA will be more rigid, but also typically more brittle and will tend to biodegrade over time (especially in a hot garage).  I think it should probably work with the settings you're using, but you might need to reprint at some point down the line.

no_of_nuts = 1

I liked the orginal design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:684948), but every model has multiple shells so I decided to fix them.
As the soft I used needs to estimate the shape of the model, it has to increase the number of triangles. It means that the size of each model is significantly increased.

Mr and Mrs Salt and Pepper Pots lovingly embraced in each others arms. Yin Yang wonderful.
  • Print without support, it's all in the geometry.
  • Removable base plug, for filling with salt/pepper/spices etc ideal printed with flexible filament.
  • One model, print twice (change colour).
  • Great for Valentines or Halloween (cos they're ghosts duhhh!!)
    • http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
    http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

Print without support, the internal shell has self supporting ceilings.
Scale to suit.
The plug can be scaled up or down to achieve best fit.
I printed the plug in the flexible Filaflex from Recreus to allow easy insertion and removal.

comments.text: Amazing Design!  First print was successful, even on my questionable quality printer.  No supports, 20% infill, full size, rock solid print.  They're going as a gift to a friend who needs a hug, not sure she'll ever need that much salt or pepper though, they hold alot!!!
comments.author: marmotjr

comments.text: Nice thing! Full scale printed well, but my 2/3 scale attempt resulted in the little ghosts having open mouths and not so fine finish under arms and at the back of their necks. The latter could be a result of only 1mm perimeter and 1mm top/bottom. The good locking thing had 1.5mm perimeter and 0.15mm layer height. It took a while to print tough... :-)
comments.author: littos

comments.text:
Thanks for your print uploads and your comments. This thing is just on the edge of being printable without support, but printable it is and without cooling too. There is a fine relationship between overhang angle and slice layer height, which you have found. For perimeters I always print the inner loops before the outer perimeter to give that last one something to bind to. You may already have found these options in your slicing software but this tip may help others.
Cheers, Steve.
comments.author: littos

title: Prusa i3 MK2 Dual Fan Duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
More available at http://prusamk2.com
Made for the Prusa i3 mk2. Blasts the air on each side of your print, preventing part curling and greatly increase the ability to print more extreme overhangs and improved bridging.
Print in petg, abs or PC.

Support is built in for the lower Mount hole. Trim off after print completes.
Duct should be mounted with the mount plate behind the parts blower fan then secured in place with screws.

Note: Works with a E3D Silicone sock in place as well.
Have also ran a 30 minute test at 245 nozzle temp with fan off. No melting or drooping with E3D Silicone sock on heater block.

Suitable for either the MK2 or MK2S.

comments.text: I just completed a two hour print with this modification and have come across two problems.  The first is that the wall where the screw goes into is too thin and the screw pulled through the plastic.  The second is that after removing the part to fix the screw damage I noticed that both sides nearest the nozzle had begun to droop.  I am using and e3d sock.  I think  the part needs to have a bit more spacing from the nozzle and a thicker wall where the screw enters.  With those modifications I think this would be great!

title: Duplicator 7 - Spatula / Flake scooper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Scrap the FEP sheet from any debris in the VAT.
The size is exactly the same as the original tank on the Duplicator 7.

LARGE: 2mm opening, will hold large chunk of cured resin. Normal flow rate.
SMALL: 1mm opening, catch everything. Low flow rate. Be carefull and slow.

Once all the bed have been done, till it a bit and lift up the gunk.
Rinse in alcohol or water, doesn't matter.

Repeat.

Some model are not there, you can find more here: https://www.cgtrader.com/M600

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Required build 90x60x3

comments.text:
The best idea for D7 !
I'm working on a total free hand cleaning automated system , because print with dlp is .....
But sometimes , it's better to avoid cleaning , and you have created the solution !!!!!!!!!!!
The resin cleaner

description.text:
OpenDungeonTiles: Curve Interior Roughstone 2x2

Assembly:
Walls take 5mm magnetic spheres
Floors take 3mm magnetic spheres
Bases take 5mm magnetic spheres
Insert 5mm magnetic spheres into the 2 holes, glue thinner piece on top. When placing other parts onto the base, the thinner glued on part should be on the bottom. (I am working on assembly video/instructions)

Open Forge Compatible.
Open Lock Compatible (Note: You must use the lock in my files it is thinner)

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

Questions - use the comments, send me a message here or on patreon.

title: [Experimental] Belt Idlers - for Bearing and for 3mm screws - 16 22 and 24 Teeth

description.text:
Use as an experiment. Strongly recommend buying metal ones ;)

After doing some tests. The original ones did break on the "lips" going to do test for the ones called "Thicker Lips" (Removed the old files)

I recommend either the 16 teeth or the 24 teeth ones for testing

So the thicker lips wont fit for example the default Y or X axis on an Anet A8. However it will fit on some X axis belt tensioners and maybe on some Y Axis modifications for belt tensioner.

Consider this still experimental and for testing purposes, not a direct replacement of any part.

September 2 2017 - Added different variations. Hopefully the file names explain which is which. Ask in the comments if not sure.

NOTICE!!! Be aware of supports when printing this. Specially when printing the bigger lips versions.

So I saw this around Thingiverse, but a user asked for a version of this idea with some walls to the sides. I guess this should work, and at the same time help making the piece stronger.

If you want to give it a try, please do so, and comment/share what you think.

Photos and feedback always welcome.

NOTE: All versions have a lip of 1.08mm

MODELS OPTIMIZED TO PRINT WITH 0,12mm Layer height

comments.text: Printed and they do not fit my A8 x axis, and is probably a bit too tight for the Y axis. They are too wide to fit in the bearing holder. The bearing holder gap on the x-axis is 8mm. I'm printing an older version with thin walls to see if that fits.

title: USB 3.0 external Harddisk case for 15mm HDDs (for 3TB and 4TB)

description.text:
2.5 inch hard drives are very handy because they need only 5Volts from the USB port and no power supply unit. The largest and cheapest per gigabyte of these 2,5" drives come in 15mm Thickness and use more platters than normal 9.5, 12.5 or 7mm notebook HDDs.
Sadly there are almost no USB3.0 cases on the market which support these thicker 15mm Harddrives.

I recently bought a Seagate ST4000LM016 4TB drive for RAWs and video backups. I got the single 15mm enclosure which was on stock for it from Raidsonic icybox, but it would not work on my mac. Must have something to do with the controller raidsonic uses.
But a chinese 4$ noname USB3.0 case from ebay worked fine. The Case identifies with a USB ID of 0x0621 and a Vendor ID of 0x1f75 (Innostor Co, Ltd.).
http://www.ebay.de/itm/USB3-0-to-SATA-External-HDD-2-5-Aluminium-Enclosure-Case-PC-HD-Hard-Disk-Drive-/282273336680?var=&hash=item41b8cd4d68:m:m7MejyXBsN6Mn4br-aF9oKw&autorefresh=true

Because the case only supported 12.5mm HDDs i made a new case to support 15mm drives. I decided to reuse the sturdy aluminium panels of the original external case and just print a new frame as this is most cost effective and has better looks and thermals compared to a pure 3d printed design. The case can be opened without any tools by pressing the front part and bending the hooks that engage the aluminium panels inside.
It took 4 design changes to get my idea and right, but the fifth print now fits perfectly.

https://youtu.be/0oL3YCuxQJI

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100micron

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used Cura 2.6.2. to slice it and it came out without any problems.

Make sure to select "Touching Buildplate only" when you use support, because otherwise it will be very hard to get the support out of the printed hooks.
A raft is not needed as the surface area that it sticks to pretty large when you are using support.

I used GRRF PLA at 205°C on a bed with 60°C and 100% Fan speed (1st layer off), 120mm/s move speed and 60m/s printing speed (first layer 30mm/s).

Removing the support completely is very important, especially in the areas of the hooks in the front and back and the groove where the controller PCB slides into.

I used some adhesive rubber foam to prevent the HDD from bouncing against the aluminium panels. Be careful with the HDDtop only to place the rubber foam at the sides where the screws are.
Putting too much pressure on the harddisk top shell or glueing something over the breathing hole can break your Harddisk!

title: FPV GoPro Session mount for Realacc X210 (QAV-X)

description.text:
This GoPro Session mount is inspired from clevis41's design. It has been modified to fit better on a Realacc X210 frame (QAV-X).

Modifications are listed below
-Ability to raise camera angle from 35deg to >60deg (if you want a specific angle, just ask !),
-Support material is recommended but not needed on this design,
-Unobstructed image: the front wall of the mount is out of the GoPro Session's field of view,
-Fits directly to the horizontal standoff of the X210/QAV-X top plate. Needs only one zip tie to secure it on the top plate.
-Lighter design, with 30% thinner walls. Don't worry, it is still crash-proof (see photos enclosed).
-Internal shape of the mount matches exactly the GoPro Session 5 shape.
-Better used with the "TBS_unify_mount" also provided, which uses the single zip-tie to secure your TBS Unify VTx, and to protect your dipole antenna from transmitting stresses to the UFL connector.

4 iterations have been made from original design to this one, which has the best anti-vibration/weight/ fitting compromise.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sVTbi-QArJA

el regulador del final de carrera nos hace mas facil hubicar el punto "HOME" si cambiamos de extrusora y no tiene las mismas dimensiones que la anterior.

description.text:
This radio tray is for the Martian-255 5" quadcopter, to help tidy up the installation of the radio equipment in the quad. The Martian is a Chinese clone of an impulseRC Alien 5" kwad https://impulserc.com/collections/alien. However, the Martian at £26 is a good budget frame being; light, compatible with all common parts, and it flies well too. This design will allow you to mount your VTX & RX simply and makes for a very tidy installation. The design caters for both the RH & LH side SMA type VTX's and you can always install an LED in the other spare hole... The design has been optimised to be printed with TPU.

Martian Frame can be bought from RadioC
http://www.radioc.co.uk/Martian-255-Alien-Clone-Carbon-Fiber-Drone-Frame-p/19902.htm

However, I should say there are two schools of thought on the solution;

  1. mounting the radio kit, RX & VTX close together is not a good idea as may cause intermodulation product and the possibility of the VTX power over driving the sensitive front end of the RX causing blocking (resulting in reduced range) (FGA),
  2. the other view suggests that there is no impact based on practical experience (LeDrib)... I would suggest that you make your own checks and draw your conclusions. But for me, it works...

@finalglideaus - suggests you should separate your RX & VTX if you are going to fly long distances - Chad likes the idea of radio hardware & the antenna of the two systems being mounted as far apart as possible.

Drew's view is that it all seems to work well, even when mounted close together, and Drew has not had a lockout yet... You can watch Drew kwad build for more detail
@drewcamden - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HltLZR9lMbQ
Move to about 23 mins 41 secs in the video.

So, this design was inspired by @drewcamden aka LeDrib... http://shop.miniquadclub.com/shop/accessories/mqc-fusion-commdock/

Drew's 'commdock' was designed for the MiniQuadClub Fusion Frame - http://shop.miniquadclub.com/shop/frames/mqc-fusion/

This radio tray has been designed specifically for the Martian 5". And has a number of features Drews doesn't have in his design namely; a front & rear brace structure, square holes in the rear brace to help align the VTX, a reduced diameter rear plug in the RX antenna tube hole to help locate RX antenna tubes. This is the 3rd iteration of this design which has been optimised to print with TPU using 2mm support structures...

Please follow Drews channels...
Twitter @Drewcamden

YouTube https://www.youtube.com/LeDribFPV

title: Dipole antenna housing for QAV-X/Realacc X210

description.text:
FPV quadcopters are always too heavy.
When weight optimization is your obsession, replacing your old-school VTx's circular-polarized antenna with a simple dipole antenna is a great way to make your fat-quad loose 10-15g very easily, with no compromise on flight performance. Paradoxically, these dipole antennas are meant to be robust and resilient, but they often tend to disconnect or break on the UFL connector, or on the coax setting. And if they survive to the crash itself, they can bend and get into a prop's path. Zing !
This little antenna protection makes your dipole antenna as tough as needed, for a weight cost of only 1.6g. It also prevents your antenna from flexing and getting cut by your props.

A must-have if, like me, you have more walk-time than stick-time.

The current model is designed to fit perfectly in the existing holes of a QAV-X/Realacc X210 frame, but it can be adapted to any other frame. If you want a specific design, please just ask !

Happy flying !

remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Filiment Guide and Z Axis Stabilizer with Bearings

title: Clip-On Filiment Guide with Bearings for Wanhao Duplicator i3 (and similar)

description.text:
This is a remixed version of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:444591 modified to clip onto Wanhao Duplicator i3 (and similar printers). You will need to download the other parts from there.

This build uses two 8mm 608ZZ (8x22x7) greased mini ball bearings.

Print 1 pulley, 1 clip-on spool guide, 4 washers, and 2 axles.

I printed as two parts:
Part-1: 1 pulley, 1 clip-on spool guide (.2mm layers and 50% infill, with support, and no brims)
Part-2: 4 washers, and 2 axles. (.2mm layers and 100% infill, with brims, and no support)

I made the tolerances very tight on the pulley, you may need to adjust the scale depending on your printer's calibration.

comments.text: What's a spinner?
comments.author: kokojie

comments.text:
This spinner goes on top of the filament feeder, which drives the extruder.
While something is printing it will spin along as the print continues. It is mostly meant to look cool, but can also help show you when the feeder motor is skipping, which might indicate either a blockage or that the print head is too tight against the build plate

title: Rx7 FB Camber Plate Riser/Spacer Newest

description.text:
A spacer/stabilizer that goes between a top mounted camber plate and reinforcement plate below the strut tower. Specific to FBS3 13B...(aka 84-85 GSL-SE)

Useful on lowered cars for regaining strut travel on McPherson setups. Specifically when using a Ground Control Camber/Caster Plate on a Mazda FBS3 13B.. Let's you reposition camber plate to above the strut tower allowing your strut rod extend an additional 10mm and provide more travel. Spacer is 10mm thick and specific to a Ground Control Camber/Caster Plate.

I'm using Taulman Alloy 910 at 75% or greater infill and 240C. PET tape covered bed @50C. Tape covered with Elmer's Washable School Glue Stick (it's purple).

USE AT YOUR OWN RISK. Short term testing proves concept. Might not be suitable for track use or extended street use.

I also have lots of caster dialed in to this model.. you might need to adjust things a bit.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kuFKisWjLzb
